comments.commentBody: "No one expected Santorum to do as well as he did running for president this year -" I still tend to think that he just got lucky that the cyclical anyone but Mitt surge just happened to raise his boat at the same time that actual voting took place, most of the other pretenders dropped out in shorty order, and the voters  who wanted to vote against Mitt had to vote FOR someone... aside from that he did have a enthusiastic core of support from among the social conservative wing of the party.

Regarding Rick "Torquemada" Santorum and the "suspension" opf his presidential campaign, I don't want to sound or be perceived as mean, cruel and/or cynical by what I'm about to say. Listen, I;m no fan of Santorum or his ideology. I'm just analyzing it purely from a political perspective.

Frankly, Santorum chose an opportune moment to call it quits. Let's be honest. His political career was over after he lost his Senate re-election bid badly in 2006. No one expected Santorum to do as well as he did running for president this year - he surprised a lot of people by doing much better than anticipated (winning I beleive 11 states).

I remember the early debates when he was placed at the end of the stage and hardly had any questions directed at him. By the last debate, Santorum was standing right next to Willard Mittford "4-Car Garage" Romney.

If Romney loses the general election to President Obama, Santorum would be regarded as one of the front-runners for 2016 - together with Romney's VP choice.

So Santorum's political career has been revived and has a future.

But if Santorum had proceeded with his campaign, and then lost the Pennsylvania primary, he would have squandered all the goodwill and everything else gained to date.

A loss in his home state would have once again ended his politcal career.

So it appears Bella's illness gave him an opportunity to leave the race gracefully, with dignity and preserve a significant upside for a political future.

Given the trajectory of Medicare,  the improbability of correspondingly massive economic growth, and the likelihood that multiple states and major cities' fiscal woes c/o pension/health care obligations for their retirees will demand federal assistance, I'd have to agree with you on this.

The Pope of Pennsylvania will get to deliver another jeremiad at the GOP convention and then slink back into oblivion (or a shot on Dancing with the Stars which amounts to the same thing).  So long, Rick: we knew yee far too well.

Michael,
Reading this column this evening, after the Santorum pull-out this afternoon, it's eerie to consider what might have been, had events turned out otherwise.
And, at the end of the day, with Santorum on all those upcoming ballots (for which it's likely too late to remove his name), it's going to be interesting to see how it all turns out.
(P.S. Finally saw you appear in person the other day on MSNBC.
It's such a pleasure to put your face with your name, as I've read so many of your articles through these years.)
This is absurd.  On what grounds did the team have the right to suspend their manager for exercising HIS right to free speech?  Is this Cuba or is it the U.S.A.?

Western European tax systems tend to be *more* regressive than our own, due to their greater reliance on VAT and gasoline taxes. Our own federal tax system is quite progressive until you consider the very, very wealthiest -- the mean effective total federal tax rates go from 1.6% to 7.3% to 14.0% to 18.3% to 24.4% on quantile boundaries. The top 0.1% pay a mean of 30.6%. And yes, this counts payroll taxes.

(see http://www.taxpolicycenter.org/numbers/displayatab.cfm?Docid=3192&Do... )

It's at the state level that our taxes are frequently regressive, since most states go for a thirds-split between sales, property and income taxes and states tend to provide significantly fewer deductions, exemptions and credits -- but state tax policies aren't a federal issue and aren't relevant to a federal election except so far as the federal government subsidizes taxpayers in high-tax states by making such expenses deductible.

Perhaps you thought you were participating in one of these competitions for speaking nonsense where you had to speak non-stop for 3 mins but nothing should make sense! Please stop embarrassing yourself!

India Ink you're generally awesome, but it would be great if you could do a follow-up article that emphasizes on ensuring a well functioning, well regulated market, rather than on the public distribution system (that is based entirely on cereal). Household dependence on food, is in large part on the market, rather than on the Government’s welfare schemes. Consumption expenditure patterns of the poor in India suggest that (despite subsidized food grain) as high of 70% of the poor’s food requirements are dependent on the market, and only about 30% of the expenditure on food of an average rural household is on cereals (as per the govt. out of every rupee spent in 2006-07 by the average rural Indian on consumption, 52 paise was spent on food. Of this, 17 paise was spent on cereals, 8 paise on milk and milk products, 6 paise on vegetables, 4 paise on sugar, salt and spices, and 4 paise on beverages, refreshments, processed food and purchased meals).

In the absence of a public distribution system covering eggs, milk, edible oil, fat and sugar, the problem of India is not just hunger; it is a hunger for nutrient rich food.

The fundamental questions you need to raise are: Should India disband its food distribution system and try something different, like simply giving out food coupons or cash? Would an increased expenditure on irrigation (rather than continuing with massive investments on the PDS) have had a more lasting impact on livelihoods and malnutrition?

Great question!

By the way, I'm a white American expat in India since 1994 -- but not with the Managing Director or VP lifestyle. Bangalore has become incredibly dysfunctional & polluted in that time. This is sad. Used to love Bangalore. Indian cities that have great commercial success (viz Bangalore/Mumbai) have the problem of attracting people until the city sinks under the load.

Now to speak of maids, we had one, Laxmi, who lost several jobs due to her bad temper. She was also our cook. I, and my Parsi wife after I married, I put up with her, which paid back with lots of loyalty. She was with me for 6 years -- until my wife and I left Bangalore. Laxmi spoke 3 languages. She lost her husband young. She & her eldest girl broke rocks to live but she raised all her 5 children to adulthood. Her 4 girls are still in the maid/cook class, but her driver son can probably earn 2x as much & her girls have learned English & Hindi to improve their earning. She & her husband delivered all her children at home. She'd rest a few minutes then cook a meal.

What would help people like her would be more networking, transparency & citizen pressure to improve public facilities. It will come. Non-resident Indians returned are a big part of the solution.

I would have paid our maid/cook more, but how much can we swim against the great tide of supply and demand in India?

Funny thing. Can't find a maid or cook in Mysore. Now I wash the dishes & sweep the apartment. My wife cooks.
does the author keep a maid in the U.S.?

>>whenever Muslims celebrate "Hinduness", they are "good Muslims"
Give me one example of this. Even recently converted Hindus will claim ancestry from the Arabs. There is never even an acknowledgement of "Hinduness" in any Muslim from India that I know of. It is not right or wrong. I am just pointing to your oxymoron statement.

>> Hindus rejecting Islam within their culture...
You should read your history. Hindus were among the most persecuted people under Muslim rule. Why would they not reject Islam? Just look to the plight of Hindus in Pakistan and see how comparatively better Muslims are faring in India. If you are going to point to the killing of Muslims in Gujarat, journalists from all religions made sure we knew what was happening. Dont know of any Hindu who would condone that massacre. There are a few Muslims who have come to the aid of that poor Christian woman sentenced to die on trumped up blasphemy charges in Pakistan.

>>Why do you care if Muslims are so obsessed with their religion? Is it because their religion evoke hate within you?

No. This obsession evokes hate for other religions, most notably against Hinduism. You cannot tolerate the fact that Hindus do not pray to the same god as the Muslims, Christians and Jews. I know that bothers many Muslims.

For the record, I am an atheist, and do think there are good people among believers of all religions, and among atheists. I dont think you are one of the tolerant ones.

Why would anyone want to drive in India? Very few drivers actually follow traffic rules and if one were to follow the rules, he/she is likely to get into an accident. Driving is not for the faint hearted there.
It is far safer to take a taxi and leave the driving to people who know how to drive in India.

True. Email, which is smartphone adaptable, has all of the photo-sharing, message-sending capabilities that any social media site does. On a funny note, yesterday I overheard a small business owner verbally mull over FB buying Instagram for $1 B, something he doesn't even use, let alone see a billion dollars of value in. His comment was "I wonder if they would like to buy a deli?"

For those who think they can delete their photos and personal details from Instagram and simply walk away, it may already be too late. Part of the takeover agreement would probably have been that Instagram's customer databases, complete with all uploaded pictures, would be preserved and handed over intact to Facebook, probably right from the date of signing the agreement. So, even if you delete your profile now, the contents would probably be backed up by Instagram into some server somewhere, all warmed up and ready for FB to sink its fangs into. Think about it: how many people would pay 1 billion dollars for just a simple photo editing software?

Another point: ever heard of farm animals being fattened up before being sold to the slaughterhouse? That pretty much sums up Instagram's users. What was Instagram's business model? To set up a business activity, and somehow make it look attractive enough for someone to buy and make the creators rich; the same as with many startup companies. So, Instagram prepared its web in a quiet corner, festooned it with juicy tidbits (its millions of users), then waited patiently--for two years. Finally, someone (Facebook) took Instagram's juicy bait of all the fattened and pampered Instagram users offered up for the feast, and ante'd up with a billion dollars in exchange. And now, the fattened animals being led away feel saddened that their former "wonderful benefactor", Instagram, got "conned" by the slaughterhouse operator. lol.

Tens of millions of deaths due to the Second World War and associated devastated infrastructure -- the vast majority of the damage outside the United States -- had less of an impact than the federal tax code?

Ever since FB made the announcement about its IPO plans, the bet's been that the company would devote its resources to absorbing Twitter. There's been many lies circulating about the latter, namely about its chances for survival despite its astounding growth, and all of it has been unfounded cynicism. It's easy to fathom FB sharing Twitter with Carlyle in the near future.
Maybe he's back in prison for some specious alleged scam?

AKLady --

Two obvious examples are 1) substantial inefficiencies and anomalies in Medicare spending (see Atul Gawande's excellent commentary on this issue, and for a study the Dartmouth Atlas) -- there are substantial inconsistencies where much expenditure appears to result in no better results; so there is much improvement that could be made in favoring best practices and not merely 'more means better results';

2) and in Social Security payments, which are structured in a fairly regressive fashion. After all, somebody who is well-educated and has a history of lucrative employment will likely collect larger Social Security payments for a longer period than somebody from a lower-class background (likely to not only earn less per annum, but also to live a shorter life, statistically speaking). In other words, the benefits will accrue most to those least likely to need them. This is not a sane feature of a nominally anti-poverty program.

This is a tough call. On the one hand, obesity and its twin menaces, diabetes and heart disease, are a very real risk for overweight people. And it has been shown that the earlier in life a weight problem begins, the harder it is to rectify. I give the mom credit for attempting to protect her daughter from these very real--and often mortal--risks.

On the other hand, a 7 year old has a lot of growing to do. With an emphasis on weight maintenance, rather than loss, it was quite possible that she could "grow into" her weight and cease to be overweight once she was tall enough to absorb the pounds. That might be safer since diets can often cause nutritional deficiencies.

That said, I don't fault the mother at all for trying to eliminate Oreos, pizza, candy and soda. These foods are basically unnecessary and not only do they provide no nutrients but they are a nutritional DRAIN on he bodies of young children---not to mention causing tooth decay.

When the opposite happens and a parent allows a child's eating habits to spiral out of control, that parent is condemned for negligence. Now, here, we have a case of a mom being condemned for taking action to control her kid's weight. It seems a mom can't win no matter what she does!
"relentless and breathless."  You are SO right.

I don't see much of a strategy here to be honest. I think that Yahoo signed its death certificate with their lawsuit against Facebook for infringing patents. Programmers definitely don't like patents because they hinder innovation and make their lives harder. They benefit big companies who have big legal teams but screw over many startups that don't have the means to challenge false patents. Yahoo is in a desperate position. This seems like a move of desperation on Yahoo's part because this type of act really damages Yahoo's perception in the tech community, which is already quite low. I think that a lot of people will even perceive this type of move as jealousy on Yahoo's part. Facebook is quite successf, is heading towards a monster IPO, and has received so much hype amongst businesses that there's dozens of companies listed at http://www.buyfacebookfansreviews.com that do nothing but promote Facebook business pages. Nothing that Yahoo has done in years has inspired any kind of similar passion and Yahoo is filled with some really horrible product managers that have squandered big-time opportunities with their key properties. Yahoo really does feel like a rudderless ship right now and I think this was a big mistake. Facebook has the means to fight off this lawsuit, regardless of the merits of the patents, and Yahoo has all of the look of a sinking ship.
